Skip to content Things to do Services Supporting businesses Visit homepage Open search area Open menu Getting help with the cost of living Contact the City Corporation About us Events Accessibility statement Councillors, committees and meetings Report, Pay, Apply Open search area About us About the City of London Corporation Organisational structure Organisational structure About us About the City of London Corporation Organisational structure Go to Facebook Go to Twitter Go to LinkedIn Go to Mail Date updated: 5/08/2025 The Senior Leadership Team The Senior Leadership Team (SLT) is chaired by the Town Clerk and Chief Executive, Ian Thomas CBE. It is the leadership team for the City of London Corporation and is comprised of Chief Officers. SLT meets weekly and plays a key role in ensuring the organisation and its institutions are aligned with the City Corporation‚Äôs strategic framework and Corporate Plan. It has officer executive oversight of major programmes, strategies, processes and systems including financial planning, the People Strategy, Digital Strategy and Transformation and ensuring everything is in line with the City of London Corporation‚Äôs ambition to be world-class in everything it does. SLT Members Ian Thomas CBE, Town Clerk & Chief Executive The Town Clerk and Chief Executive leads the City of London Corporation‚Äôs staff under the policy guidance of the Court of Common Council and the Policy and Resources Committee in a visible, inspirational, and inclusive manner, ensuring the economic, efficient, and effective delivery of the City Corporation‚Äôs policies, and public, charitable, and private services. He ensures the strategic objectives of the organisation are being vigorously pursued and that high standards of conduct and performance are maintained throughout the organisation. He conducts meetings of the Court of Common Council, the Court of Aldermen and Common Hall on behalf of the Lord Mayor, is the principal advisor on matters of policy through the Policy and Resources Committee and is the Electoral Registration Officer. The Town Clerk's department is responsible for a number of areas of work, including servicing meetings of the Court of Common Council and Court of Aldermen , their committees, sub-committees and working parties. The Town Clerk chairs his Senior Leadership team on a weekly basis. It plays a key role in agreeing strategy and reviewing performance across the organisation to ensure it is world-class in everything it does. The team focuses on key priorities including promoting Financial and Professional Services competitiveness and technology; making the City a world leading destination; and ensuring it is a leader in achieving net zero and a global centre for green finance and expertise; it is also working to reset the City Corporation‚Äôs relationship with residents and helping our SMEs thrive. The work of this and other groups helps provide Members and the public with the assurance that matters coming to committee for decision have received appropriate oversight at a senior level. Caroline Al-Beyerty, Chamberlain and Chief Financial Officer The Chamberlain, Caroline Al-Beyerty, is the Chief Financial Officer of the City of London Corporation and Head of Profession for Finance across the service and corporate departments and institutions. Her team drives innovations in technology and ensures the effective financial management of the City Corporation‚Äôs affairs. As the Chief Investment Officer, the Chamberlain is responsible for the City Corporation's local and private trust funds. The Chamberlain‚Äôs team has key enabling functions for how the organisation does business, through the Digital Information & Technology Service and Commercial Services. The Commercial Service is a key component in the transformation of how the City Corporation manages change, its project portfolio and how it purchases and pays for the goods, works and services it needs. The Chamberlain is also an essential ceremonial figure for the City Corporation, playing a vital role in the installation of new Lord Mayors and administering the admission to the Freedom of The City. She is also responsible for constituting new City Livery Companies and interpreting and amending their ordinances and charters. Michael Cogher, Comptroller and City Solicitor, Deputy Chief Executive The City Comptroller & City Solicitor, Michael Cogher, through his department is responsible for providing all legal services required by the City Corporation. This includes providing legal advice to committees, departments, to the City Police Commissioner and to other organisations for whom the role is required to act as legal adviser (eg the Museum of London). The main areas covered include commercial property and land law, housing, litigation, employment law, contract law, planning, trusts and company law. His department deals with over 2,000 new legal matters every year and this covers anything from heavyweight property acquisition and disposals to horse riding byelaws in Epping Forest. Michael is also the City Corporation‚Äôs Monitoring Officer and Senior Information Risk Owner. As a result, his department is also home to the Information Governance Team, who advise in relation to data protection and Freedom of Information matters and to the Electoral Services Team who are responsible for City, Parliamentary and GLA elections and maintaining the City‚Äôs Electoral Registers. Dionne Corradine, Chief Strategy Officer The Chief Strategy Officer, Dionne Corradine, leads the Corporate Strategy and Performance Team driving an integrated and insightful approach to strategy, equity, equality, diversity and inclusion, planning, risk management, and Chief Officer governance across the City Corporation. The team delivers and enables maximum impact on Corporate Plan outcomes by providing advice, quality assurance and insights, at the right time, to the right people so they can make the best possible decisions.‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã Responsibilities also include optimising and aligning Corporate Performance and departmental Business Planning to deliver cross-cutting objectives. The team oversees Corporate Risks, making sure mitigations are in place to minimise disruption to strategy implementation, operations and services. It also ensures that equality and diversity are observed in corporate standards and in service delivery. The team has an emphasis on collaboration and continuous improvement, maintaining the organisation's agility, responsiveness and readiness to tackle challenges and opportunities now and in the future. Judith Finlay, Executive Director of Community and Children‚Äôs Services The Executive Director of the Community and Children's Services Department, Judith Finlay, has responsibility to provide the necessary care and support to the City‚Äôs resident and worker population. Her department covers people, housing, education, early help, children and adults social care and community services for residents which includes safeguarding and quality assurance, support to looked after children, virtual school, homelessness and rough sleeping, education and early years. It also has a wider remit for both residents and workers in relation to public health (a shared service with the London Borough of Hackney), leisure and adult education. These services range from apprenticeships to adult skills and also include the provision of Barbican and Community Libraries across the Square Mile. The department is responsible for the maintenance and repairs programme of our existing properties including the Barbican Estate , Middlesex Street Estate, Golden Lane Estate and ten other estates situated in six different London boroughs and for building new affordable homes. Judith‚Äôs team is also responsible for commissioning and partnerships across services and London on such issues as community safety. Cliff Morton, Chief People Officer (Interim) The Chief People Officer, Cliff Morton, is the Head of Profession for Human Resources across the City Corporation. The HR function plays an important part in providing strategic and operational HR support across the organisation‚Äôs Corporate and Service Departments, as well as Institutions, playing a pivotal role in its people achieving success. The HR team supports the whole life cycle of all City Corporation employees - from recruitment to colleagues moving on, and everything in between. This includes recruitment, performance management and learning and development, HR are the guardians of people management information and data recording which is key to modernising and transforming the City Corporation's services. The team has launched the organisation‚Äôs first People Strategy which is an important part of the employer/employee relationship. It will help create an exceptional, values-based work environment where people feel deeply connected with the City Corporation‚Äôs vision and values and have the skills, recognition, motivation and reward to deliver the Corporate Plan. Greg Moore, Deputy Town Clerk The role of the Deputy Town Clerk, Greg Moore, is to oversee the co-ordination of political and policy advice to the City Corporation's leaders and Members, the support of the Corporation‚Äôs decision-making processes, and a number of other key areas of cross-cutting corporate activity. This involves the Governance & Member Services section, which supports more than 500 decision-making meetings each year; the programme management and private offices of the Lord Mayor and Chairman of the Policy & Resources Committee, through the Mansion House and the Office of the Policy Chairman; the City Corporation‚Äôs Strategic Security & Resilience service, helping to protect the City, ensure business continuity, and recovery; the organisation‚Äôs responsibilities as a police authority, in support of a safe and secure City; Corporate Health & Safety; Support Services for the wider Town Clerk‚Äôs department; and the London Metropolitan Archives, which house not only the City‚Äôs own records but those of many other bodies, serving as a public research centre specialising in London history. Damian Nussbaum, Executive Director, Innovation and Growth Executive Director of Innovation and Growth, Damian Nussbaum, works to strengthen the UK‚Äôs Financial and Professional Services (FPS) competitiveness to create jobs and growth right across the UK and reinforce the UK‚Äôs position as the world's leading global hub for FPS to support a thriving economy. His team also promotes and supports this offer globally by building and delivering the City Corporation‚Äôs leading international trade and investment programme. It works to improve access to key markets, as well as shape a world-class business and regulatory environment for UK-based firms and those doing business with and through the UK. Additionally, the Department‚Äôs Destination City team is focussed on increasing footfall and bringing visitor spend back to pre-pandemic levels by seeking to enhance the area's attractiveness as a place to be for business, workers, visitors and residents. The City Corporation has adopted a radical Climate Action Strategy which breaks new ground and sets out how the organisation will achieve net zero, build climate resilience and champion sustainable growth. This work is led by the department‚Äôs Climate Action Strategy Team. Katie Stewart, Executive Director Environment As Executive Director of the Environment Department [starting 22 July 2024] , Katie Stewart is responsible for the largest department within the City Corporation with 800 staff working across 25 sites, providing key front-line services to the City and beyond. In the Square Mile the team deliver local authority and regulatory functions including planning and development; building control; highways and transportation; cleansing and waste; environmental health, licensing and trading standards. Further afield, they manage more than 11,000 acres of amazing open spaces, including Epping Forest and Hampstead Heath, capturing 16,000 tonnes of carbon a year and attracting 25 million visitors. The team also run the City of London Cemetery and Crematorium; the Heathrow Animal Reception Centre; provide animal health services London-wide; and, as the London Port Health Authority, check imported food and animal feed. Paul Wilkinson, City Surveyor and Executive Director of Property The City Surveyor and Executive Director of Property, Paul Wilkinson, is responsible through his department for the management of the City Corporation‚Äôs property investment and corporate real estate portfolios and major property/construction projects. In addition, Paul is responsible for the Central Criminal Court (Old Bailey) and the three wholesale markets at Billingsgate, New Spitalfield and Smithfield. The City Corporation has significant property ownership in the Square Mile, with other investment ownerships in Westminster, Camden, Southwark and beyond, covering Inner and Outer London Boroughs. The income generated on these assets helps support the public value goals of the organisation. Therefore, the City Surveyor is focused on maximising rental income and delivering long-term performance across the organisation‚Äôs investment property estates. It is also developing long-term redevelopment opportunities close to the City. The City Surveyor‚Äôs Department oversees the asset management functions in relation to the City Corporation‚Äôs operational property portfolio, including flagship assets such as the Guildhall, Barbican Complex, the three wholesale markets and the Central Criminal Court. It provides repairs and maintenance, and facilities management services to all non-housing City Corporation property, including leading on the buildings element of the Corporation‚Äôs Climate Action Strategy (CAS). It provides strategic management to the City‚Äôs significant heritage portfolio, including scheduled monuments, listed buildings, historic open spaces, churchyards and cemeteries, public statuary, ceremonial furnishings, and historic carriages. It jointly oversees the Markets Co-location programme, Sailsbury Square development, Museum of London relocation and Barbican Renewal project. Paul Wright, The Remembrancer The Remembrancer, Paul Wright, is one of the City's four Law Officers and the Office is responsible for the maintenance and protection of the City‚Äôs constitution. He is the City's Parliamentary Agent and the Parliamentary Agent for the Honourable the Irish Society, and the City's Chief of Protocol. The Office was created in 1571 and was closely allied to the Monarch and the Court. This is reflected in some of the functions of Paul‚Äôs team today which include liaison between the City and the Royal Households and the Diplomatic Corps. The Remembrancer‚Äôs Department also acts as a channel of communication between Parliament and the City. This means examination of, and briefing on, proposed legislation and amendments, liaison with Select Committees of both Houses and contact with Government officials dealing with Parliamentary Bills. In addition, it organises events and hospitality on behalf of the City Corporation - from small receptions to major State occasions. "The City of London Corporation is a unique organisation. For 900 years, we‚Äôve been at the heart of London. We‚Äôve helped the capital transition from a small settlement to an international powerhouse and the home of the country‚Äôs financial and professional services sector which employs 2.5m people across the whole country. Today, our Senior Leadership Team is guided by our enduring mission as the governing body of the Square Mile, dedicated to a vibrant and thriving City, supporting a diverse and sustainable London, within a globally-successful United Kingdom." "Nowhere else would you find an organisation dedicated to providing the brilliant basics and statutory services at a local level, shaping sustainable environments at a national level, and leading on issues like artificial intelligence at the global level. Every member of SLT brings deep leadership and delivery experience from across multiple sectors to our Chief Officer group and I‚Äôm proud of our commitment to working collaboratively as one team to offer solutions to the important issues of the day." Ian Thomas CBE, Town Clerk & Chief Executive The Executive Leadership Board The Executive Leadership Board (ELB) is chaired by the Town Clerk and Chief Executive, Ian Thomas CBE. This cross-City Corporation leadership board comprises of Chief Officers, Heads of Institutions and a Police Authority Board representative. ELB meets every month. This officer leadership board is responsible for aligning strategy and connecting plans across all the organisations which make up the City of London Corporation. ELB also has oversight of major risks, corporate performance, strategic people considerations and has Equity, Diversity and Inclusion as an integral part of its agenda. ELB also has a particular focus on collaboration and how the organisation works with and through others including stakeholders, partners, and diverse communities. Caroline Al-Beyerty, The Chamberlain and Chief Financial Officer Michael Cogher, Comptroller and City Solicitor, Deputy Chief Executive Dionne Corradine, Chief Strategy Officer Judith Finlay, Executive Director of Community and Children‚Äôs Services Cliff Morton, Chief People Officer (Interim) Greg Moore, Deputy Town Clerk Damian Nussbaum, Executive Director of Innovation & Growth Katie Stewart, Executive Director, Environment Department Paul Wilkinson, City Surveyor and Executive Director of Property Paul Wright, The Remembrancer Alan Bird, Head, City of London School Jenny Brown, Head, City of London School for Girls Simon Latham, Acting Managing Director, City Bridge Foundation Emma Markiewicz, Director, The London Archives Roland Martin, Head, City of London Freemens School Pete O‚ÄôDoherty, Temporary City of London Police Commissioner Richard Riley, Director, City of London Police Authority David Farnworth, Interim Chief Executive, Barbican Jonathan Vaughan, Principal, GSMD Jen Beckermann, Executive Director, Private Secretary to the Chair of Policy & Resources Caroline Jack, Executive Director, Private Secretary to the Lord Mayor Chief Officer Risk Management Group The Chief Officer Risk Management Group (CORMG) is a sub-group of the ELB that meets every two months and supports it in its overall responsibility for risk management. Apply now 2025 LOC Board of Directors The LOC is governed by a board of directors consisting of four officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer and Immediate Past President) who serve one year in each position, and 12 directors who serve three-year terms. Nine directors are elected city officials, and three directors are appointed city staff. In the first year of the appointed city staff member‚Äôs term, they are non-voting. During the final year of the appointed city staff member‚Äôs term, they serve, with the four officers, on the LOC‚Äôs Executive Committee. The LOC Board also has several non-voting members, including past presidents who have retained either an elected or appointed position with a member city.¬† Non-voting members may also include elected officials who have been appointed to the LOC Board to represent an otherwise unrepresented region of the state.¬† These elected officials would serve a one-year term on the board. General The Town of Cross Citystrives to ensure that its services are accessible to people with disabilities. TownofCrossCity.com has invested a significant amount of resources to help ensure that its website is made easier to use and more accessible for people with disabilities, with the strong belief that every person has the right to live with dignity, equality, comfort and independence. Accessibility on TownofCrossCity.com The Town of Cross Citymakes available the UserWay Website Accessibility Widget that is powered by a dedicated accessibility server. The software allows TownofCrossCity.com to improve its compliance with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.1). Enabling the Accessibility Menu The Town of Cross City accessibility menu can be enabled by clicking the accessibility menu icon that appears on the corner of the page. The best way to maximize your reach on social media is to cross-promote your content and share it across multiple platforms. Getting your business in front of more eyes helps you stay top of mind at crucial buying times. We know that the audiences are slightly different across all three and they might want different content, so we‚Äôve made sure you have the best tools to re-create your posts quickly. How can I create a post across platforms? Now when you‚Äôre saving a finished post, you‚Äôll find a new option to save and re-create the same piece of content for your alternate social platform. We‚Äôll take the image and text from your original post and set it up ready for you to edit the caption to fit the new platform and new audience. We‚Äôll then help you schedule it at the right time. Here‚Äôs how! Can I re-share a great post from the past? Absolutely! You might discover through your analytics that a post performed really well on Instagram and you‚Äôd like to re-share it to Facebook and see how it works there. You‚Äôll now find a menu when searching through your published posts that gives you the option to repost. (Pssst, there are no limits on how many times you can re-share. You can re-share a Facebook post back to Facebook over and over if it‚Äôs something that you know always performs!) Instagram vs. Facebook vs. LinkedIn As a general rule, most people are visiting Instagram to be inspired, and love seeing products and businesses sharing the ‚Äòlifestyle‚Äô feel of their brand. Think shorter, witty captions with strong call-to-actions, coupled with eye-catching imagery. Those scrolling Facebook usually have a little more time to read informative articles and spend more time engaging with content. It‚Äôs a great place to try adding long form copy. It‚Äôs more about variety and getting meatier content out there for a more diverse audience to click to ‚Äòsee more‚Äô if they‚Äôre interested. LinkedIn viewers usually have a business skew to their posts, whether it‚Äôs sharing a professional milestone, keeping in touch with old colleagues or learning about what‚Äôs news in the industry, it‚Äôs one of the fastest-growing B2B platforms and we‚Äôre excited to support them. There are always exceptions to the rules so we recommend keeping an eye on your analytics to see what works best for you to get your audience clicking on your posts. Now when you‚Äôre scheduling posts for Facebook, we‚Äôve made sure your full media collections are available. You‚Äôll be able to select any image from your previously uploaded Instragam collections. Image Holy Cross Magazine has undergone several iterations during its lifespan. The alumni publication debuted in 1927 as a newsletter entitled ‚ÄúThe Alumnus.‚Äù Four decades later, in 1967, it became ‚ÄúCrossroads.‚Äù In 1997, the publication evolved into a traditional magazine format and size, renaming itself ‚ÄúHoly Cross Magazine.‚Äù Its latest evolution, in 2024, includes the launch of an immersive website that showcases human-based stories and topics through vibrant videos, extraordinary photography, scintillating audio, and genuine narratives. As the magazine continues its print legacy, it too has experienced an update to match its 21st-century digital counterpart. In creating the latest version of the College‚Äôs informational hub, Holy Cross Magazine looked to the past, resurrecting an icon that appeared at the turn of the last century: the interlocking HC that appears here and on the magazine‚Äôs cover is at least 120 years old. Image Senior Designer and Art Director Stephen Albano discovered the logo in the College‚Äôs Archives & Distinctive Collections holdings years ago. It appeared on the uniform of Timothy F. Larkin, class of 1905, who played quarterback for the football team before later coaching it. A Worcester native, he was inducted into the Holy Cross Varsity Club Athletic Hall of Fame in 1958. In its latest storytelling journey, the magazine remembers its past, and embraces its future while emphasizing what makes Holy Cross special: its people. City Manager - Town of Cross City Skip to content City Clerk City Manager Utility Information Town Council Accessibility Meetings and Events City Clerk City Manager Utility Information Town Council Accessibility Meetings and Events Search Home About Us Government Accessibility Fair Housing Equal Opportunity Employer Minority & Women Business Town Council Town Departments City Clerk City Manager Police Department Utility Information Pay Your Bill Police Department Public Notices Calendar Contact Us City Manager The Town of Cross City operates under the Council-Manager form of government. The Town Council is elected by the voters and in turn, the Council appoints a professionally trained individual as its City Manager. It is the responsibility of the City Manager to handle day to day operation of town business. The Town Council makes policy decisions, and votes on all legislative or quasi-judicial matters required or enabled by state or federal law. The current City Manager is John Driggers. The City Manager is the Chief Administrative Officer of the Town and is responsible for all major non-policy decisions for the Town. All departments other than that of the City Clerk fall under the City Manager. Use tab to navigate through the menu items. Who We Are Cross impact is an outreach to students on secular campuses. We desire to enable and equip Bible-centered churches to carry out the Great Commission on one of the most strategic mission fields on earth, the secular campus. A Little History Cross Impact Campus began in 1986 under a different name, Spurgeon Foundation Campus Ministries. The heartbeat of the ministry is the local church ‚Äì connecting the college student to a loving, spiritual family that will shepherd him or her into a walk with the Lord throughout life.¬† So, Cross Impact is not primarily a mission board seeking support for missionaries to the campus, but a ministry of the local church encouraging other churches to reach out to the campus in their Jerusalem. Cross Impact's founder is Pastor Will Senn. He was saved and first discipled on a secular campus. He started Cross Impact's first chapter at Clemson University and pastored University Baptist. He authored the book: " Taking the Cross of Christ to the Campus: A Manual for Church-Based Campus Ministry. " Pastor Will Senn is the senior pastor at Tri-City Baptist Church in Westminster, CO and currently serves as the President of Cross Impact's board. Pastor Will Senn Keith Huhta served as a missionary for 32 years in Mexico. During his time in Mexico, he ministered at Ebenezer Bible Institute, training many men and women for Gospel ministry. He ministered there as the Dean of Men, Academic Dean, and the Director. He brings his administrative skills, ministry experience, and prayerful spirit to the role of Cross Impact Director. He began this role in January of 2020 and looks forward to helping this ministry of Cross Impact move forward. Director Keith Huhta Interview with the Founder Address: 6953 West 92nd Lane Westminster, CO¬† 80021 (Tri-City Baptist Church) Email: national.office@crossimpact.org Phone: 720-472-2347 TAKING THE CROSS OF CHRIST TO THE CAMPUS. so students can be EQUIPPED FOR LIFE IN CHRIST. bottom of page

About Us | Who Are We | City & County Healthcare Group Find your local branch enquiries@candchealthcare.co.uk About Us Who We Are People First Vision and Values Our Companies Our People Technology Our Services Homecare Complex care Live-in care Extra care Learning disabilities Supported living Become a Care Professional Latest Jobs News Contact Us Menu About the CCH Group family Who We Are At CCH Group, we‚Äôre more than a care provider ‚Äì we‚Äôre a passionate community dedicated to driving the sector to new heights with a history of doing so. Founded in 2009, we‚Äôve grown into the nation‚Äôs largest care company, with over 260 locations and 14,000 care professionals delivering 1.5 million hours of care each month across the UK. The best of both worlds: the strength of a sector leader, with the care of a local partner Our network of 32 operating companies combines national strength with local expertise to deliver care that is deeply embedded in the communities we serve. While our local presence ensures responsiveness to local challenges and fosters familiarity, we also recognise the advantages of our scale. Our size and breadth enable us to attract top-tier support teams with specialised departmental expertise, drive efficiencies, deliver state-of-the-art systems, and provide stability. We are innovative to the core We have a history of innovation that will not stop. When we saw that social care was lagging in technology, we built and embedded revolutionary new solutions to support our frontline. When quality improvements were needed across the sector, we recruited a leading team focused on ensuring dependable and safe care. In payroll, we developed systems to ensure on-time and accurate payment. When communication across our 14,000 employees proved difficult, we introduced a sector-leading communications platform for a remote workforce and gave everyone a voice. Time and again, our innovations have raised the bar, setting new benchmarks for quality, reliability, connectivity, and efficiency across the sector. Our goal is to redefine what it means to work in care and, in doing so, elevate the entire sector. CCH Group is backed by Summit Partners. People First, Always We have a vision to become the best place to work in care. We firmly believe that putting our people at the heart of the company is not only the right thing to do, but it also ensures they are in the best position to provide extraordinary care to everyone who relies on us. Culture counts here: Our playbook In our house, People-First is not just a buzzword; it is how we operate. To build a thriving company and ensure continuous improvement, we listen to our frontline to better understand their needs and respond to them. Here are some initiatives we have launched based on the insight gathered: Engaging and Nurturing Team Training: A comprehensive training across our entire branch network to equip our teams with the tools to communicate more effectively, recognise contributions, and support our care professionals. CCH Connect: Our internal communications platform that enables employees to connect, stay informed about company news, voice their opinions, recognise peers, and access essential resources. People First Engagement Programme: A programme of touchpoints with our care professionals ‚Äî fostering two-way communication, regularly checking on their well-being, and giving them opportunities to voice their needs. Coffee Mornings: Regular informal gatherings at branches for care professionals to build connections and share experiences. Festive Parties: We celebrate a year of hard work by hosting more than 200 Christmas parties for our branch teams and care professionals across the company. Gifts are given to all employees. Extraordinary Care Awards: Monthly recognition of outstanding contributions made by our care professionals and branch teams, culminating in prestigious regional and national award ceremonies. Over 300 individuals are honoured each month. Branch of the Month: A celebration of top-performing branches to create a performance culture and recognise hard work. CCH Ambassadors: Frontline representatives who act as a steering committee, guiding decisions for the Group and meeting with the CEO monthly to give input. ‚ÄúAchieving greatness as a care provider starts with fostering a positive employee experience. When we empower our workforce, nurture their well-being, and create a leading culture, our people are in the best place to support those we care for.‚Äù ‚Äì Gary Fee, CEO Vision & Values Our vision, mission and values We are made up of 32 operating companies but have one vision: to become the best place to work in care. We firmly believe that putting our people at the heart of the company is not only the right thing to do, but will also ensure that they are in the best position to provide extraordinary care to everyone who relies on us. Our vision Our vision is to become the best place to work in care. Our mission Our mission is to expand our reach so that those in need of care are not forgotten or alone. We will achieve this by nurturing our people, elevating their role in society so that together we can transform lives. Our values COMMUNITY We are stronger together. One team building a culture where our customers and our people thrive. COURAGE We boldly shape a better future. We tackle challenges head-on. HEART We are passionate and dedicated. We love what we do because what we do matters. The Home Care Association City & County Healthcare Group is a member of the Home Care Association, adhering to their¬†Code of Practice. Our Companies At CCH Group, our family of operating companies is united by a shared vision: to create the best place to work in care. Each company brings deep local knowledge and unique specialisms, ensuring that our care is not only personal but also grounded in the communities we support. Guided by our core values of community, courage, and heart, each of our companies empower their teams to make a meaningful difference every day, building environments where both care professionals and the people they care for feel truly valued and supported. City & County in 2022 as Chief Operating Officer, and moved into the role of Chief Executive Officer in June 2023. Gary brings extensive strategic and financial experience from his time in the education, food and support services sectors. City and County Healthcare Kris Lee Chief Financial Officer Kris Lee brings senior leadership experience across retail, IT, logistics and banking to his role as CFO. Known for driving transformation through strategic insight and hands-on leadership, he is focused on aligning finance with care priorities, embedding performance frameworks, and enabling data-led decisions that deliver measurable impact across the organisation. City and County Healthcare Julie Hunter Chief of Quality JJulie Hunter, RGN, brings in-depth experience in both domiciliary and residential care. With a background in operations and governance, she leads the development of robust quality systems and best practice at CCH, ensuring safe, effective care through strong oversight, continuous improvement and a commitment to excellence. City and County Healthcare Jackie Kent Chief People Officer Jackie Kent is an experienced HR leader with expertise in people strategy, talent development and culture change. As Chief People Officer, she is focused on building a high-performing people function, driving engagement and supporting CCH‚Äôs ambition to be the best place to work in care through a values-led, people-first approach. City and County Healthcare Denise Priest Chief Commercial Officer With over 25 years of senior leadership experience from Bright Horizons, Denise has a proven track record in navigating complex, highly regulated environments. Her expertise in corporate services, particularly in supporting working families to achieve a harmonious work-life balance, aligns seamlessly with our people-centric approach where we provide essential care services to communities. City and County Healthcare Jonathan Smith Chief Information Officer Jonathan Smith is a digital transformation leader with experience across health and care, retail and consultancy. As CIO, he leads CCH‚Äôs innovation agenda, using emerging technologies, data and partnerships to drive integrated digital solutions that improve care outcomes, empower teams and shape the future of person-centred care. City and County Healthcare David Hillier Non-Executive Chairman David spent his early career in healthcare, where after working in UK hospital management he took part in the creation of Capio Sant√©, the leading French hospital network which he led as CEO, based in Lyon, before becoming CEO of the UK hospital group Capio Healthcare UK (later Ramsay Healthcare UK) in 2006 backed by private equity in which capacity he provided a range of surgical, medical and psychiatric services to both the NHS and private sector. David left Ramsay in 2008 to lead Groupe Proclif the foremost Parisian PE-backed healthcare network where as Directeur General he oversaw the development and successful sale of the group. He then returned to the UK as CEO of ADP Dental, a leading provider of NHS dental services, where he led the turnaround and sale of the chain. In 2011 David created Independent Vetcare, originally a UK-based veterinary group which under his leadership grew rapidly through organic initiatives and acquisitions to become IVC Evidensia, Europe‚Äôs largest veterinary care provider, operating a network of over 1,500 veterinary clinics, as well as specialist hospitals, emergency services, crematoria and online retail, with market-leading positions across 12 countries including the United Kingdom, Scandinavia, Germany, France and Netherlands and employing over 20,000 staff and care professionals. David retired from his role as CEO of IVC Evidensia in 2020. City and County Healthcare Technology Elevating care through technology At the core of everything we do is a simple belief: quality care starts with meaningful connections. As social care evolves, so do we. With people living longer and the demands on Local Authorities growing, we‚Äôre transforming care without losing sight of what really matters ‚Äì our clients and the care professionals who support them. That‚Äôs why we created Model Branch ‚Äì a digital platform that‚Äôs changing the way we deliver care. By embracing technology, we‚Äôre not just keeping up with the times; we‚Äôre enhancing the quality of care our clients receive and giving our care professionals more time to build the relationships that make all the difference. Putting people first ‚Äì always For us, it‚Äôs all about ensuring that everyone in our community receives the best care possible. Model Branch takes the hassle out of paperwork, giving our care professionals more time to focus on what they love ‚Äì spending quality time with the people they care for. This technology also helps us spot areas where we can do even better, ensuring our services are always tailored to meet each person‚Äôs unique needs. As Catherine Porter, one of our regional managers, puts it, ‚ÄúNow that we‚Äôve gone digital and removed all the paperwork, it means that our care professionals have more time to spend with our clients.‚Äù With Model Branch, we can: Keep care on track: Daily monitoring and easy adjustments mean clients get exactly what they need, when they need it. Stay up-to-date: Care plans are updated in real time, so they always reflect what‚Äôs happening right now. Spend more time with clients: Less paperwork means more time to connect with those who matter most. Supporting our care professionals We know that providing great care takes both heart and dedication. Model Branch is designed to make things easier for our care professionals, giving them more time to do what they do best ‚Äì caring for people. By simplifying the day-to-day tasks, we‚Äôre creating a work environment where our team can truly shine, making us the best place to work in care. With Model Branch, we can: Tailor care plans: We make real-time adjustments, ensuring that care is always spot-on for each person. Create better schedules: By matching service user needs with location, we make sure the right care is there at the right time. Cut down on admin work: Less paperwork means more hands-on care and connection. Building trust through transparency Trust is the foundation of our community, and transparency is key to building that trust. Model Branch gives us a clear view of how care is being delivered, helping us make informed decisions and respond quickly to any changes. This technology ensures that everyone involved ‚Äì from families to commissioners ‚Äì has the information they need when they need it. With Model Branch, we can: See care in real-time: Accurate, location-based reporting lets us know exactly what‚Äôs happening, as it happens. Share information clearly: Transparent reporting keeps everyone in the loop and builds trust. Respond to needs quickly: Informed decisions help us meet the growing needs of our community. Social care is evolving, and CCH Group are leading the way with a focus on community, courage, and heart. We‚Äôre here to make sure that care is always centred around one thing ‚Äì people. Reach out to our team today to see how Model Branch can help us continue to deliver exceptional care, together.
